Accidental Release Prevention Policy:

Protecting and responsibly managing natural resources demonstrates stewardship and is critical to the quality of life in the communities we serve, to the environment, and to WTG Gas Processing, L.P.'s (WTG's) long-term business success.  Promoting the health and safety of co-workers, contractors, customers, and communities is the responsibility of all WTG employees.  WTG will meet all applicable laws, rules and regulations.



Stationary Source and Regulated Substances Handled:

Sale Ranch Gas Plant (Sale Ranch), located in Stanton, Martin County, Texas, is a natural gas liquids (NGL) recovery plant that produces pipeline specification natural gas and NGL, also known as Y-grade, from field gas collected throughout the upstream gathering system.  Sale Ranch processes flammable gas and liquid mixtures in an amount greater than the threshold quantify containing any of the following RMP-regulated constituents:

?    Methane

?    Ethane

?    Propane

?    Isobutane

?    Butane

?    Isopentane

?    Pentane



The only RMP-regulated toxic constituent present at Sale Ranch, which is part of the amine treating process for the sites' liquid product, is hydrogen sulfide; however, quantities at this facility are well below the threshold quantity. 



Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies:

WTG is committed to ensuring a safe work environment for all its employees, contractors, and vendors.  The Sale Ranch Gas Plant has a detailed Emergency Action Plan in which it has coordinated with the community's local responders through mock emergency simulations in order to introduce the local responders to the facility and its personnel.



General Accidental Release Prevention Program:

The Sale Ranch process is covered by OSHA 29 CFR 1910.119, Process Safety Management of highly hazardous chemicals (PSM) regulation.  WTG considers the systems developed for compliance with PSM to be the basis for good safety and business practices.  In this

effort, WTG identifies opportunities to continuously improve initiatives for each PSM element.  The PSM elements are implemented to satisfy the PSM requirements and are discussed here for completeness only since the Sale Ranch Gas Plant qualifies as a program level 1 RMP process.



Employee Participation:

Employee participation is the foundation block to an evergreen and integrated PSM program.  Thus, the current PSM improvement initiative is heavily focused on this key element as employees are becoming more actively involved in the implementation of each element of PSM.



Process Safety Information:

Comprehensive reviews of the available process safety information (PSI) have been conducted.  Updates to maximum intended inventory (MII) and piping and instrumentation diagrams (P&IDs) have been completed as a result of a September 24, 2018 incident that resulted in significant damage to the front end of the gas plant.  This incident led to a redesign and rebuild of the inlet processing equipment at the plant, which was shut down from September 24, 2018 until January 17, 2019.  Additional information about this incident is discussed in the Five-Year Accident History section.  A comprehensive electronic web-based system utilized for timely access to information has been built, implemented, and made available to all personnel involved with operating the process.  The updated MII and P&IDs are available in this electronic web-based system, as well as other pertinent process information. 



Process Hazard Analysis (PHA):

A PHA that included experienced operating personnel (operations and maintenance), WTG engineers, Process Control personnel, safety representatives, and PSM representatives was utilized to conduct a new PHA in June 2018.  Results and recommendations from these analyses were shared with employees.  Additionally, a process safety tracking tool has been developed and implemented for the interactive tracking of PHA action items to closure.



The redesign

mentioned above required a revised PHA review.  The revised PHA was conducted on December 5, 2018 using the Hazards and Operability (HAZOP) methodology and was limited to the equipment damaged during the September 24, 2018 incident:  inlet gas compression, liquids separation, and stabilizer process.  The status of all PHA items from the June 2018 and December 2018 PHAs are being maintained in the process safety tracking tool.



Operating Procedures:

Written operating procedures referencing PSI are available in the site project books.  Operating procedures were updated prior to restart of Sale Ranch in January 2019 and operators were trained prior to the restart of the updated facility.  A technical review of the updated operating procedures is on-going to ensure current operations are reflected and to incorporate the various modes of process operations.  Completed procedures are published to the company's electronic web-based system.  In addition, a mentorship training program has been implemented.  



Management of Change (MOC) and Pre-Startup Safety Review (PSSR):

Improvements to the MOC procedure and associated checklists are in progress to capture all process related changes.  Requirements for the identification, evaluation, control, and authorization of modifications to plant design and operations prior to the implementation to ensure that the risk of new or existing hazards are properly managed is available to all personnel.  Extensive PSSR checklists for applicable disciplines (electrical, instrumentation, procedures, etc.) have been developed and implemented.  These checklists are Appendices to the Company's MOC procedure and are available online from the company's electronic web-based process library.  The MOC procedure was used for the redesign of the inlet gas processing equipment at Sale Ranch and all MOCs were reviewed in the PHA and with all employees affected by this process.



Mechanical Integrity (MI):

In addition to the ultrasonic thickness

testing program already in practice at Sale Ranch, a complete third-party MI gap assessment has been completed.  This has resulted in the development of revised comprehensive inspection standards and procedures along with a customized inspection program to be implemented onsite in 2019 through 2020.



Incident Investigation:

WTG investigates all PSM incidents as part of the PSM program assessment process.  As part of WTG's PSM improvement program initiative, incident investigation procedures are being reviewed and will be updated as necessary.  A mix of WTG personnel will be provided investigation methodology training to further enhance the program and ensure root cause is consistently identified.  A process safety tracking tool has been developed and implemented to track action items and incident investigation corrective actions to closure. 



Depending on the severity of a given incident, WTG will contract with third-party contractors that specialize in incident investigations to perform this task and such was the case with the September 24, 2018 incident.  The incident investigation began on September 25, 2018 with an on-site investigation at the scene of the incident.  The scene investigation included thorough documentation of the scene, evidence identification, and reviews of witnesses and facility documentation. This evidence was used to identify the root cause, direct cause, and contributing factors to the incident by the incident investigation team.  The investigation team, lead by the third party contractor, also made several recommendations to prevent recurrence of the incident and enhance emergency response capabilities.  Most of these recommendations had already been designated as part of WTG's PSM improvement initiative.



Compliance Audits:

To meet compliance with PSM, WTG conducts compliance audits every three years to verify all PSM element requirements are being satisfied.  In WTG's general PSM improvement program initiatives, an updated audit

protocol has been established and implemented within WTG.  The most recent compliance audit began in August 2018 and was completed in September 2018.



Hot Work Permit:

Hot work permits are in use and on file.  These permits are uploaded onto the company's electronic web-based process library and/or maintained at the plant site control room.  Throughout the PSM program assessment process, all hot work procedures are being reviewed and will be updated as necessary.



Contractors:

WTG has an electronic program for contractors that includes their safety records.  A review of the contractor's safety record both prior to selection and during their time of employment is being developed.  Written contractor and visitor safety orientation training materials have been developed and implemented at Sale Ranch.  WTG is in process of developing a safety training video that all contractors and visitors must see before gaining access to the Sale Ranch Gas Plant. 



Training:

With the enhancement of various PSM elements such as PSI, PHAs, operating procedures, PSSR, MI, MOC, incident investigations, etc., additional training (computer and classroom based) will be established to ensure all Sale Ranch employees are knowledgeable in these processes.



Chemical Specific Prevention Steps:

The process at Sale Ranch has hazards that must be managed for continued safe operation.  Following is a description of existing safety features applicable to prevention of accidental releases of regulated substances in the facility.



Universal Prevention Activities

The accident prevention program summarized previously is applied to the RMP-covered process at Sale Ranch.  Collectively, these prevention program activities help prevent potential accident scenarios that could be caused by equipment failures and human errors.



Specialized Safety Features:



The Sale Ranch Gas Plant has safety features on many units to help:

I.    contain/control a release

II.    quickly detect a release

III.    red

uce the consequences of (mitigate) a release

Release Detection

I.    Hydrocarbon detectors with alarms located throughout the process

II.    Hydrogen sulfide detectors with alarms located in designated process areas

III.    Routine operator rounds/equipment inspections

IV.    Operators are on-site continually (8,760 hours per year)



Release containment/control measures include:

I.    Main process relief valves that discharge to a flare to capture and incinerate episodic releases

II.    Automated and manual valves to permit isolation of the process

III.    Automated shutdown systems for specific process parameters (e.g., high temperature)

IV.    Curbing to contain liquid releases

V.    Redundant equipment and instrumentation (e.g., uninterruptible power supply for process control system.

VI.    Atmospheric relief devices



Release mitigation measures include:

I.    Fire extinguishing systems

II.    Personnel trained in emergency action

III.    Personal protective equipment (e.g., chemical protective clothing, self-contained breathing apparatus)



Emergency Response Program:

The overall emergency response program for Sale Ranch has been coordinated with several local emergency responders that include the Stanton Fire Department ("FD") and Emergency Medical Services ("EMS"), Midland FD, Lenorah FD and EMS.  The Sale Ranch Gas Plant has around-the-clock communications capability with appropriate emergency response organizations (e.g., fire department, Police and Sheriff's office).  This interface provides the means of notifying the public of an incident, if necessary, as well as facilitating quick response to an incident.  Sale Ranch conducts mock emergency drills that involve the LEPC and emergency response organizations and the facility will conduct additional emergency drills annually with local emergency responders regarding the hazards of regulated substances in the facility.  The emergency response plan was last updated on February 11, 2019.



Five-Year Accident History:

A primary

loss of containment incident occurred on September 24, 2018 when a ball valve assembly failed, resulting in the release of inlet field gas at high pressure.  The released gas contacted an ignition source that resulted in a fire.  Sale Ranch operators had begun an Emergency Shutdown (ESD) immediately upon detection of the gas release.   Field inlet gas was shut down by the shutdown of the surrounding compressor stations feeding the gas plant.  As the field gas could not be isolated from the process, it served as fuel to the fire which lasted for 17 hours.  The fire resulted in significant onsite property damage at the inlet to the gas plant with no operator or contractor deaths or injuries.  There are no known offsite impacts.  Therefore, this incident is being reported under the RMP accident history reporting requirements but does not affect the program level status of the site per 40 CFR 68.10(f)(1).



Planned Changes to Improve Safety

WTG Sale Ranch will continue to improve its safety and environmental performance through emphasis on the continued development of it's PSM Program.  Improvement plans include process engineering support to update critical PSI data for the site; operating procedures written for each mode of operation and to include consequences of deviations; an operator certification training program established from the new operating procedures, new process hazard analysis (PHA) procedure and team structure ensuring employee involvement, new MI program incorporating the implementation of all new inspection procedures and frequencies all to be carefully reviewed, and recommendations for improvement generated using WTG's new compliance audit process.
